title: 2010 Coca-Cola 600
text:
The 2010 Coca-Cola 600, the 51st running of the <a href="Coca-Cola%20600">event</a>, was a <a href="NASCAR">NASCAR</a> <a href="Sprint%20Cup%20Series">Sprint Cup Series</a> race held on May 30, 2010 at <a href="Charlotte%20Motor%20Speedway">Charlotte Motor Speedway</a> in <a href="Concord%2C%20North%20Carolina">Concord, North Carolina</a> as the 13th race of the <a href="2010%20NASCAR%20Sprint%20Cup%20Series">2010 Sprint Cup season</a> It also was the longest race of the 2010 season, having consisted over 400 laps and .
<a href="Kurt%20Busch">Kurt Busch</a>, driving the No. 2 car for <a href="Penske%20Racing">Penske Racing</a>, won the race while <a href="Jamie%20McMurray">Jamie McMurray</a> for <a href="Earnhardt%20Ganassi%20Racing">Earnhardt Ganassi Racing</a> (whose team won the <a href="2010%20Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a>) finished second. The race had 17 different leaders, 34 lead changes, and eight cautions.
Race report.
Background.
<a href="Charlotte%20Motor%20Speedway">Charlotte Motor Speedway</a> is one of ten <a href="Oval%20track%20racing%23Intermediate">intermediate tracks</a> to hold <a href="NASCAR">NASCAR</a> races; the others are <a href="Atlanta%20Motor%20Speedway">Atlanta Motor Speedway</a>, <a href="Kansas%20Speedway">Kansas Speedway</a>, <a href="Chicagoland%20Speedway">Chicagoland Speedway</a>, <a href="Darlington%20Raceway">Darlington Raceway</a>, <a href="Homestead-Miami%20Speedway">Homestead-Miami Speedway</a>, <a href="New%20Hampshire%20Motor%20Speedway">New Hampshire Motor Speedway</a>, <a href="Kentucky%20Speedway">Kentucky Speedway</a>, <a href="Las%20Vegas%20Motor%20Speedway">Las Vegas Motor Speedway</a>, and <a href="Texas%20Motor%20Speedway">Texas Motor Speedway</a>. The standard track at Lowe's Motor Speedway is a four-turn, -long, <a href="Oval%20track%23Quad-oval">quad-oval</a> track. The track's turns are <a href="Banked%20turn">banked</a> at twenty-four degrees; both the front stretch (the location of the finish line) and the back stretch (opposite the front) have a five-degree banking.
The Coca-Cola 600 was conceived by race car driver <a href="Curtis%20Turner">Curtis Turner</a> who built the Charlotte Motor Speedway. It was first held in 1960 in an attempt by NASCAR to stage a <a href="Memorial%20Day">Memorial Day</a> weekend race to compete with the open-wheel <a href="Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a>; the two races were held together on the same day starting from 1974. The race is the longest in terms of distance on the NASCAR calendar and is considered by several drivers to be one of the sport's most important races alongside the <a href="Daytona%20500">Daytona 500</a>, the <a href="Brickyard%20400">Brickyard 400</a> and the <a href="Bojangles%27%20Southern%20500">Southern 500</a>. The long distance makes it the most physically demanding event in NASCAR, and teams adapt to changing track conditions because the race occurs between late afternoon and evening. It was known as the World 600 until 1984 when <a href="The%20Coca-Cola%20Company">The Coca-Cola Company</a> purchased the naming rights to the race and renamed it the Coca-Cola World 600 in 1985. It has been called the Coca-Cola 600 every year since 1986 except for 2002 when the name changed to Coca-Cola Racing Family 600.
Practice and qualifying.
Three practice sessions and qualifying were held before the Sunday evening race; one practice and qualifying on Thursday and two on Saturday. In the first practice, <a href="Juan%20Pablo%20Montoya">Juan Pablo Montoya</a> was quickest, ahead of <a href="Ryan%20Newman%20%28racing%20driver%29">Ryan Newman</a> in second, <a href="Jimmie%20Johnson">Jimmie Johnson</a> in third, <a href="Elliott%20Sadler">Elliott Sadler</a> in fourth, and <a href="Kasey%20Kahne">Kasey Kahne</a> in fifth. In the second practice, Kasey Kahne was fastest while <a href="Kurt%20Busch">Kurt Busch</a>, <a href="David%20Reutimann">David Reutimann</a>, Jimmie Johnson, and <a href="Jeff%20Burton">Jeff Burton</a> followed. During final practice, the quickest five were <a href="Martin%20Truex%2C%20Jr.">Martin Truex, Jr.</a>, <a href="Denny%20Hamlin">Denny Hamlin</a>, Kasey Kahne, <a href="Greg%20Biffle">Greg Biffle</a>, and Jimmie Johnson.
In qualifying, Ryan Newman won the <a href="pole%20position">pole position</a>, while <a href="Kurt%20Busch">Kurt Busch</a>, <a href="Martin%20Truex%2C%20Jr.">Martin Truex, Jr.</a>, Kasey Kahne, and Jimmie Johnson completed the top-five positions. During qualifying, <a href="Brad%20Keselowski">Brad Keselowski</a> and David Ragan both spun, but Keselowski collided with the <a href="SAFER%20barrier">wall</a>. Four drivers did not make the race; they were <a href="Reed%20Sorenson">Reed Sorenson</a>, <a href="Max%20Papis">Max Papis</a>, <a href="David%20Stremme">David Stremme</a>, and <a href="Mike%20Bliss">Mike Bliss</a>.
Race summary.
At 5:00 p.m. EDT, <a href="Fox%20Broadcasting%20Company">Fox</a> started broadcasting; the race would be the last they would broadcast until the <a href="2011%20Daytona%20500">2011 Daytona 500</a>. At the start of the race, the weather was predicted to be mostly cloudy. At 5:55 p.m. EDT, pre-race ceremonies began; first, Dr. James Dobson, founder of <a href="Focus%20on%20the%20Family">Focus on the Family</a>, delivered the <a href="invocation">invocation</a>. Afterward, the track hosted a moment of silence. Then, the <a href="U.S.%20National%20Anthem">national anthem</a>, was performed by the <a href="U.S.%20National%20Guard">U.S. National Guard</a> choir. To start engines, John Faulkenbury, President of the <a href="United%20Service%20Organizations">USO</a>, N.C. joined by the Dickens (<a href="United%20States%20Marine%20Corps">USMC</a>), Foley (U.S. Army) and Barnes (U.S. Air Force) gave the command "Gentlemen, Start Your Engines!"
At 6:20 p.m., the <a href="Racing%20flags%23Green%20flag">green flag</a> waved as <a href="Ryan%20Newman%20%28racing%20driver%29">Ryan Newman</a> led the field down to the start/finish line. On lap 3, <a href="Jimmie%20Johnson">Jimmie Johnson</a> said that he believed there was oil on the track. Outside polesitter <a href="Kurt%20Busch">Kurt Busch</a> passed Newman a short time later and pulled away from Newman with a 2.30-second advantage by lap 24. On lap 29, Busch started putting cars a lap down. Green flag <a href="pit%20stop">pit stop</a>s began on lap 50 when <a href="Kasey%20Kahne">Kasey Kahne</a> made a pit stop. On lap 52, Busch gave the lead to <a href="Joey%20Logano">Joey Logano</a> when he made his pit stop. Two laps later, Busch reclaimed the lead. The first caution of the race came out on lap 61 <a href="Juan%20Pablo%20Montoya">Juan Pablo Montoya</a> spun and hit the inside <a href="SAFER%20Barrier">wall</a>. <a href="Denny%20Hamlin">Denny Hamlin</a> stayed off pit road, while most drivers made pit stops.
The race started on lap 66, with Hamlin in the lead. A lap later, Kurt Busch retook the lead from Hamlin. The second caution came out on lap 91 <a href="Marcos%20Ambrose">Marcos Ambrose</a> collided with the wall. Most leaders would pitt under this caution. The race started on lap 95 with Jimmie Johnson in the lead. A lap later, Kurt Busch passed him for the lead, but couldn't keep it. So Johnson retook the lead and remained there until lap 130, when <a href="Kyle%20Busch">Kyle Busch</a> took it. Three laps later, the race passed its 200-mile mark. On lap 144, another round of green flag pit stops began. The different leaders during pit stops were Ku. Busch and Jamie McMurray, but Ky. Busch reclaimed the lead on lap 150. The third caution came out on lap 166 when Johnson got loose, collided with the outside wall, came down the track, and shoved Hamlin in the grass. Most lead lap cars made pit stops but during the yellow-flag pit stops, Ky. Busch collided with <a href="Brad%20Keselowski">Brad Keselowski</a> while exiting pit road.
On the restart, Kurt Bush led them to the green flag. Afterwards, he led until lap 213, when the fourth caution came out for debris. The restart happened on lap 217, with <a href="Clint%20Bowyer">Clint Bowyer</a> the new leader. One lap later, Kurt Busch reclaimed the lead. Kurt Busch led until green flag pit stops which began on lap 264. On lap 267, <a href="David%20Reutimann">David Reutimann</a> passed Kurt Busch for the lead. Two laps later, Reutimann made a pit stop, giving the lead to <a href="Matt%20Kenseth">Matt Kenseth</a>. On lap 272, the fifth caution came out. The cause of the caution was that Jimmie Johnson got loose, spun around, collided with the outside wall, then he went down the track and hit the inside wall; his car sustained heavy damage. On lap 277, Matt Kenseth brought the field to the restart. One lap later, Kurt Busch, from a fast start, passed Kenseth.
Kurt Busch led the race until lap 299 when Jamie McMurray passed him. One lap later, <a href="Robby%20Gordon">Robby Gordon</a> collided with the wall, and brought out a caution. During pit stops, Brad Keselowski stayed out to lead a lap, then he gave the lead to Kurt Busch when he made a pit stop. Two laps after the 306 restart, the seventh caution came out because <a href="Greg%20Biffle">Greg Biffle</a> collided with the wall. On lap 313, Kurt Busch brought the field for the restart. After chasing down Kurt Busch, Jamie McMurray finally reclaimed the lead. On lap 350, green flag pit stops began; one lap later Jamie McMurray and Kurt Busch made pit stops, giving the lead back to David Reutimann. On lap 353, Reutimann made a pit stop and gave the lead to <a href="Tony%20Stewart">Tony Stewart</a>, then he made a pit stop to give the lead to <a href="David%20Ragan">David Ragan</a> and <a href="Dale%20Earnhardt%2C%20Jr">Dale Earnhardt, Jr</a>. Earnhardt, Jr. stayed out until lap 366, when he made a pit stop. Jamie McMurray was the leader afterwards. On lap 376, the eighth caution came out because Marcos Ambrose lost control and collided with the wall. During pit stops, <a href="Jeff%20Gordon">Jeff Gordon</a> and <a href="Mark%20Martin">Mark Martin</a> stayed out, to start first and second on the restart on lap 381. One lap later, Kurt Busch surged by the field to become the leader. Kurt Busch remained the leader to win his second race in the <a href="2010%20NASCAR%20Sprint%20Cup%20Series">2010 season</a>.
